Present location: BIBLIOTHECA ALEXANDRINA ANTIQUETIES MUSEUM [01/027] ALEXANDRIA BAAM
Technique: WRITTEN WITH A REED PEN/REED WITH SPLIT NIB
Name: Papyrus Fragment Recording Part of a Play by Menander
Description: A papyrus fragment from the Oxyrhynchus collection, recording one of the plays of the Greek poet, Menander, the father of modern comedy. Comedy flourished in the fourth century BC., after the ancient tradition of comedy that was led by Aristophanes. Menander was known for some of his plays until the twentieth century AD, when most of his works were discovered written on papyrus and buried in Egypt. Eight plays were discovered, some of which were complete. Most of his works were rewritten, as they were dated to the period between the third century BC and the fifth century AD. He enjoyed great popularity in the world of comedy during the Hellenistic and Roman periods in Egypt.
